Title: Dynamics in Buddhist Networks in Eastern Central Asia, 6th-14th Centuries

This project proposes a groundbreaking framework to understand the dynamics of cultural encounter and religious transfer in pre-modern Eastern Central Asia. Focusing on Buddhism, our research will reconstruct the complex networks of exchange and localization that shaped the region's religious landscape from the 6th to the 14th centuries. By adopting a trans-regional and trans-cultural vision, we will analyze the intricate relationships between Chinese, Indian, Tibetan, Khotanese, Uyghur, Tangut, and Kitan cultures, revealing the multi-layered dynamics of Buddhist transmission and adaptation.

Through an interdisciplinary approach combining philology, art history, archaeology, and religious studies, we will investigate the spatial and temporal aspects of Buddhist networks, highlighting the agency of local actors and the role of cultural encounter in shaping religious transfer. Our unique perspective will demonstrate how the analysis of religious exchange as a dynamic network can shed new light on the history of Eastern Central Asia and its significance in comparative religious studies.

By integrating Eastern Central Asian Buddhism into the broader field of comparative religious studies, this project will provide a nuanced understanding of the complex dynamics of cultural exchange and religious transfer, contributing to a more comprehensive understanding of the region's rich cultural heritage.
